questions.text: What is the range of value of Bispectral index (BIS) for a patient who is under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The Bispectral index value range of 40-60 is seen in a patient under general anesthesia. 

The bispectral index (BIS) is an empirically derived scale that helps to monitor the depth of anesthesia and prevent intraoperative awareness. It processes the EEG and provides an index value between 0 to 100 that indicates the patient’s level of consciousness.

Bispectral index value range: 

  • 100 - Awake and response to normal voice present
  • 80 - Light/moderate sedation (May respond to loud commands or mild prodding/shaking)
  • 60 - General anesthesia (Low probability of explicit recall, Unresponsive to verbal stimulus)
  • 40 - Deep hypnotic state
  • 20 - Burst suppression
  • 0 - Flatline EEG

questions.text: A newborn presents with bilious vomiting and bloody stools a few days after birth. An upper GI contrast study revealed midgut volvulus due to intestinal malrotation. The image below is a diagrammatic representation of the findings of the contrast study. Identify the defective mechanism.
questions.solution:
The given diagram shows the transverse colon lying behind the superior mesenteric artery and the duodenum, indicating reversed rotation of the midgut loop. Only the 1st rotation occurring in a clockwise direction (instead of the normal anticlockwise) is the defective mechanism.

Midgut rotation: The mechanism of midgut rotation is given and represented in the image below. 

The midgut, once formed, lies outside the abdominal cavity and has to rotate and enter the abdominal cavity. When viewed ventrally, this rotation occurs for 270° in an anti-clockwise direction with the axis formed by the superior mesenteric artery. The artery divides the intestinal loop into a pre-arterial and post-arterial segment.

The total rotation can be divided into three stages of 90° each:

Stage 1/1st rotation - Initially, the loop lies in the sagittal plane, the pre-arterial segment cranial, and the post-arterial segment caudal. The first 90° anticlockwise rotation results in the pre-arterial segment lying on the right and the post-arterial segment lying on the left of the axis.

Stage 2/2nd rotation - The pre-arterial segment undergoes lengthening to form coils of the jejunum and ileum. The second 90° anticlockwise rotation results in the coils of the jejunum and ileum lying behind the superior mesenteric artery and occupying the posterior left half of the abdominal cavity. As a result, the duodenum also lies behind the artery.

Stage 3/3rd rotation -  In this stage, the post-arterial segment enters the abdominal cavity with the last 90° anticlockwise rotation, resulting in the transverse colon lying in front of the superior mesenteric artery and the cecum lying on the right in the abdominal cavity, just below the liver. The cecum gradually descends to its final location in the right iliac fossa.

Other options:

Option B: Only the 1st rotation occurring only in an anti-clockwise direction presents with the colon and cecum in the left and small intestine on the right, resulting in a left-sided colon.

Option C: Absence of the 3rd rotation and failure of the descent of cecum can result in a sub-hepatic cecum.

Option D: Absence of the 2nd rotation results in the pre-arterial segment lying on the right and the post-arterial segment lying on the left of the axis.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is diagnosed with epilepsy and is started on phenytoin for management. She presented to the emergency with abdominal pain, dysuria, and hypertension. She was confused and disoriented. A provisional diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria was made. Which of the following is false about this condition?

ALA - δ-aminolevulinic acid

PBG - porphobilinogen

choices.text: ALA and PBG increased in urine and plasma

questions.solution:
Blistering skin lesions are not seen in acute intermittent porphyria. They are characteristic features of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). 

Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) is a hepatic porphyria inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It occurs due to a deficiency of HMB-synthase/uroporphyrinogen I synthase enzyme in heme synthesis. AIP is generally latent before puberty and is more common in women. 

Reduced carbohydrate intake during fasting or illness can precipitate acute attacks of AIP. This occurs due to the upregulation of ALA synthase 1 (ALAS1) by hepatic peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ coactivator 1α (PGC-1α), thus increasing heme biosynthesis. Attacks can also be provoked by infections, surgery, and ethanol. A large number of drugs are classically known to precipitate AIP.

AIP presents with neurovisceral symptoms and no cutaneous manifestations are seen. The clinical features of AIP include:

  • Abdominal pain is the most common symptom.
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Tachycardia, restlessness, tremors, and excess sweating are due to sympathetic overactivity
  • Psychiatric symptoms like anxiety, insomnia, depression, disorientation, hallucinations, and paranoia can occur in acute attacks.
  • Seizures
  • Proximal muscle weakness and sensory loss
  • Dysuria and urinary retention
  • Persistant hypertension

Diagnosis can be made with the appearance of classic symptomology after exposure to an underlying precipitating factor. Plasma and urine ALA and PBG levels are significantly raised during an acute attack and remain high even after symptoms resolve.

Management of AIP:

  • Intravenous hematin as first-line treatment
  • Narcotic analgesia for abdominal pain
  • Phenothiazine for nausea, vomiting, restlessness, and anxiety
  • Carbohydrate loading with intravenous glucose
  • Removal of precipitating factors
  • Orthoptic liver transplant is curative in patients refractory to hemin therapy.

Blistering skin lesions are characteristic features of porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT). PCT is a cutaneous porphyria caused due to deficient uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase enzyme. It predominantly presents with cutaneous features like blisters, milia, hypertrichosis, and hyperpigmentation over sun-exposed areas. Neurologic features are absent.

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

questions.text: As the medical officer of a factory, you advise installing a water purification system to treat polluted water which is a by-product of the manufacturing process. The method of water purification is chosen and the blueprint is as shown below. Which of the following is true about this method of purification?

choices.text: Loss of head allowed is 2-2.5 metres
Highly skilled labor is required to operate the filter
Preliminary treatment involves chemical coagulation and sedimentation

questions.solution:
The blueprint depicts a picture of a slow sand filter where bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters up to 99.9-99.99%. Rapid filters clear bacteria up to 98-99%

Slow Sand Filters:

These are also called biological filters. They are accepted as the standard method of large-scale water purification. The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.

Rapid Sand Filters:

They are also called mechanical filters and are another method of large-scale purification of water. Two types of rapid sand filters are gravity type (e.g. Paterson’s filter) and pressure type (e.g. Candy’s filter).

Steps in the purification of water by rapid sand filters are:

  • Coagulation – Raw water is first treated with a chemical coagulant like alum, the dose of which varies from 5 to 40 mg or more per liter depending upon color, turbidity, temperature, and pH value of the water.
  • Rapid mixing – The treated water then undergoes violent agitation in a mixing chamber which allows complete dissemination of alum throughout the bulk of the water.
  • Flocculation – Slow and gentle mixing of water in a flocculation chamber is done for 30 minutes. Usually, a mechanical type of flocculator is used which has paddles that rotate at 2 to 4 RPM (rotations per minute) with the help of a motor. This results in a thick, copious flocculate of aluminum hydroxide.
  • Sedimentation – The coagulated water is moved into sedimentation tanks where detaining it for 2 – 6 hours will result in the settling down of the flocculant along with impurities and bacteria. This is to be removed before the filtration takes place. 
  • Filtration – The partly purified water is then subjected to rapid sand filtration.
    • Filter beds: Each unit of the filter bed has a surface of about 80 to 90 m2. The effective size of the sand particles/grains is about 0.4 to 0.7 mm. The depth of the sand bed is about 1 meter and has graded gravel below it.
    • As the filtration is done, the alum-floc which has not precipitated is held back by the sand bed. This forms a layer that adsorbs bacteria and other impurities. When the loss of head in a rapid sand filter approaches 7 – 8 feet, the filter needs to be cleaned by a process known as backwashing.

Comparison between rapid and slow sand filters: 

Property Rapid sand filter Slow sand filter
Space Less space Large area
Rate of filtration 200m.g.a.d 2-3m.g.a.d
Effective size of sand 0.4-0.7mm 0.2-0.3mm
Preliminary treatment Chemical coagulation and sedimentation Plain sedimentation 
Washing Backwashing Scraping the sand bed
Operation Highly skilled Less skilled
Loss of head 2-2.5m / 6-8feet 1.5m / 4feet
Removal of turbidity Good Good
Removal of color Good Fair 
Removal of bacteria 98-99% 99.9-99.99% 


The blueprint given below depicts rapid sand filtration

Related Pearl: Slow Sand Filters

  • These are also called biological filters.
  • They are accepted as the standard method of large scale water purification.
  • Essentially, elements of a slow sand filter include
    • Supernatant (raw) water
    • Bed of graded sand
    • Under-drainage system
    • System of filter control valves
  • Supernatant water:
    • It lies above the sand bed and its depth varies from 1 – 1.5 metres.
    • The level of supernatant or raw water is always kept constant and this helps in overcoming the resistance of filter bed, promoting the downward flow of water through the sand bed.
    • It also provides for a waiting period during which the water undergoes partial purification by sedimentation, oxidation and particle agglomeration.
  • Sand bed:
    • This is the most important part of a slow sand filter.
    • Its thickness is generally around 1 metre.
    • The sand grains must be rounded and have an effective diameter of 0.2 – 0.3 mm. They must be clean and free from organic matter.
    • A layer of supporting, graded gravel, 30 – 40 cm deep, prevents the grains from being carried into drainage pipes.
    • The sand bed filters the water as it percolates slowly through it through processes like mechanical straining, oxidation, sedimentation and adsorption.
    • Vital layer: In a new filter, the bed merely acts as a mechanical strainer. But over time the sand bed get covered with a Schmutzdecke/vital layer/zoogleal layer/biological layer. This is a slimy and gelatinous layer that contains algae, diatoms and plankton. The formation of such a layer is the ripening of the filter and this layer is the heart of a slow sand filter. It removes organic matter, prevents bacteria from flowing through and oxidizes ammoniacal nitrogen into nitrates, thus rendering the water bacteria-free.
  • Under-drainage system:
    • A system of porous and perforated pipes, at the bottom of the filter bed, is part of the under-drainage system.
    • They provide an outlet for the filtered water and a support to the filter medium above.
    • The under-drainage system along with the supernatant water and sand bed is kept in a filter box, which is usually 2.5 to 4 metres.
  • Filter control:
    • The outlet-pipe system is provided with valves and other devices which maintain a constant rate of filtration.
    • The Venturi meter measures the bed resistance or the loss of head.
    • When the resistance builds up, the operator opens the regulatory valve to maintain a steady-state of filtration.
    • When the loss of head exceeds 1.5 metres (4 feet), it is uneconomical to run the filter.
    • If the regulatory valve has to be kept fully open as the bed resistance is very high, the filter needs to be cleaned.
    • This is done by scraping the sand bed, which doesn’t need to be done by skilled labor. After several years of operation (say 20 to 30 scrappings) the sand bed can be changed as it would have diminished in size.
  • Advantages of slow sand filters:
    • Simple to construct and operate.
    • Cost of construction is cheap compared to rapid sand filters.
    • Physical, chemical and bacteriological quality of the water is very high which is partially owed to the long duration taken for filtration.
    • Bacteria are cleared more effectively than rapid filters.

questions.text: Which is the incorrect statement regarding the condition shown in the image?

choices.text: Inframammary area  and intermammary folds may be involved
TNF alpha inhibitors can be used in treatment
Obesity and smoking are associated with it
Surgery cannot be done for this condition.

questions.solution:
The given image shows hidradenitis supurativa or inverse acne. Surgical excision is the best treatment that offers a cure.

Hidradenitis suppurativa is a chronic, inflammatory, recurrent, debilitating, follicular disease that usually presents after puberty.

There are painful, deep‐seated inflamed lesions in the apocrine gland‐bearing areas of the body, most commonly the axillary, inguinal, and anogenital regions.

This definition is based on the San Francisco modification of the Dessau criteria.

The following three criteria must be met for the diagnosis to be made:

  1. Typical lesions - deep‐seated, painful nodules or ‘blind boils’; abscesses, draining sinuses, bridged scars, and paired or multiheaded open pseudocomedones in secondary lesions.
  2. Typical topography - axillae, groin, perineal and perianal region, buttocks and infra‐ and intermammary folds.
  3. Chronicity and recurrence of lesions. 

More common in young women of ages 20-29 years. Obesity and smoking are the two main factors associated with hidradenitis suppurativa.

Treatment includes: 

  • Antibiotics - tetracycline, clindamycin
  • Intralesional corticosteroids
  • Immunosuppressants
  • Acitretin
  • Anti-TNF alpha therapy
  • Surgery

questions.text:
A 52-year-old female patient presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive hearing loss at higher tones. She also classically complains of difficulty in understanding speech and inability to feel her contact lenses. Audiometric tests were done as follows. What is the diagnosis?

Recruitment - absent
Rollover phenomenon - present
Short increment sensitivity index (SISI) - 16%
Stapedial reflex - absent
Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) - Interaural latency of wave V is >0.2ms
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the interpretation of audiometric tests, is suggestive of the diagnosis as Vestibular schwannoma.

Vestibular schwannoma is a benign tumour arising from the vestibular nerve due to the abnormal proliferation of Schwann cells. Bilateral vestibular schwannoma is seen in neurofibromatosis type 2. It is common in both sexes between 40-60 years of age. It usually presents with unilateral tinnitus and progressive retro-cochlear sensorineural hearing loss at higher tones with poor speech discrimination. 

Tumour growth presents with corneal and facial hypesthesia (inability to feel the contact lens in the given case) due to the involvement of the trigeminal nerve. Involvement of the facial nerve presents as hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall, known as the Hitzelbergers sign and defective taste and lacrimation. Involvement of lower cranial nerves presents as dysphagia, aspiration, voice change, and regurgitation. Rarely cerebellar symptoms may also be seen.

  • Pure tone audiometry reveals sensorineural hearing loss, particularly in high frequencies.
  • Speech audiometry shows the roll-over phenomenon.
  • The absence of the recruitment phenomenon is noted.
  • Short Increment Sensitivity Index (SISI) ranges from 0-20%.
  • Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) demonstrates a significant delay of >0.2 ms in wave V between the two ears.
  • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) with gadolinium contrast is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

Surgical removal by X-knife, Gamma knife, or Cyberknife is the treatment of choice. Radiotherapy has no role. 

Other options:

Option A - Presbycusis is the physiological hearing loss due to old age and usually manifests at 65 years of age. Presbycusis occurs due to sensory, neural, metabolic, and conductive pathologies and presents predominantly cochlear hearing loss patterns. High-frequency hearing loss with tinnitus are the presenting complaints with positive recruitment phenomenon. Additional features of corneal hypesthesia are absent. 

Option B - Meniere's disease, also known as endolymphatic hydrops, occurs due to overdistension of the inner ear with endolymph. It is more common in males than females. It may be unilateral or bilateral. Cardinal features are:

  • Episodic vertigo
  • Fluctuating hearing loss of cochlear type
  • Tinnitus  
  • Sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.

Option C - Noise-induced hearing loss(NIHL) is a preventable cause of hearing loss and is an occupational hazard. NIHL causes damage to outer hair cells more than the inner hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. There is symmetrical hearing loss and shows a cochlear pattern on audiometric tests. The audiogram in NIHL shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz, both for air and bone conduction. Speech frequencies are also affected.

Related Pearl: Speech audiometry

Consists of two components:

  • Speech reception threshold: The minimum intensity at which 50% of the words are repeated correctly by the patient.
  • Speech discrimination score: The patient’s ability to understand speech.
    • Percentage of phonetically balanced words delivered 30dB above SRT which are identified correctly.
    • In normal persons and those with conductive hearing loss, a high score of 90–100% can be obtained.
    • It is reduced in cochlear lesions, very poor and out of proportion to hearing loss in retrocochlear hearing loss, and worst in cortical deafness.

Roll-over phenomenon:

  • Feature of retrocochlear hearing loss.
  • When speech intensity is increased above a particular level, SDS falls instead of maintaining a plateau as in cochlear deafness.

Uses:

  • To differentiate organic from non-organic hearing loss.
  • To differentiate cochlear from retrocochlear lesions.
  • To find the intensity at which discrimination score is the best which is useful for fitting a hearing aid.

*Short Increment Sensitivity Index: A normal ear can’t differentiate short increments of sound but a recruiting ear can. SISI test is started sound 20db above the hearing threshold of the patient and 20 increments of 1db are given every 5 seconds. The total number of increments heard by the patient is recorded. SISI score of 70-100% is seen in cochlear deafness and of 0-20% in retrocochlear deafness.

** Threshold tone decay: It is a function of nerve fatigue. A Tone of 4000Hz is presented at 5dB above the patient’s threshold of hearing for 60 seconds. A normal ear can hear continuously for a minute but a patient with abnormal hearing stops hearing before 1 minute. Loudness is increased until the patient can hear the sound. If loudness has to be increased by more than 30dB, it indicates retrocochlear hearing loss.

questions.text: A snake catcher presents with headache, vomiting, difficulty in opening his mouth, and body ache. He is profusely sweating and there is generalized stiffness and tenderness of muscles. An image of the collected urine specimen is shown below. A bite from which of the following snakes is likely to be responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing dark brown or tea-colored urine are suggestive of a bite by a sea krait.

The sea krait belongs to the subfamily Hydrophidae, which also includes other sea snakes. The snake's venom is myotoxic.

Some common symptoms include headache, thirst, sweating, and vomiting. Generalized muscle ache, stiffness, and tenderness occur subsequently. Trismus is an early symptom and is followed by generalized flaccid paralysis similar to elapid neurotoxicity.

Myoglobin released from damaged skeletal muscles causes renal failure and myoglobinuria occurs after a bite, which manifests as the patient passing dark urine that is brown, red, or tea-colored. Potassium released from damaged muscles causes hyperkalemia which can cause cardiac failure.

Other options :

Option A: Bites of Elapidae like Cobras, Common Kraits, Mambas, and Coral Snakes, generally result in neurotoxic effects in the patient. The early symptoms usually include vomiting, hypersalivation, headache, the heaviness of the eyelids, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, hyperacusis, dizziness, and ‘gooseflesh’. Paralysis first presents with ptosis followed by external ophthalmoplegia. Later paralysis of other muscles continues with respiratory paralysis as the end result.

Options C and D: Bites by Viperidae like Saw scaled viper, Russell viper, or Pit Viper usually produce more severe local effects. There may be persistent bleeding from the wound site, venipuncture, or injection sites. Spontaneous systemic hemorrhage, gingival bleeding, epistaxis, hematemesis, hemoptysis, subconjunctival, retroperitoneal, and intracranial hemorrhages can occur.

questions.text: A patient newly diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia is started on fludarabine. A few days later, he develops vomiting, abdominal pain, and hematuria. His laboratory results reveal new-onset impaired kidney function, hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, hyperuricemia, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels. Which of the following conditions has he developed?
questions.solution:
The patient has developed tumor lysis syndrome. The patient has been started on fludarabine, a cytotoxic drug to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The cytotoxic drug causes lysis of tumor cells, leading to hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia. The uric acid crystals and calcium phosphate precipitate in the tubules and cause damage to the epithelium, subsequently causing renal failure. 

Patients with impaired renal function, high tumor burden, and elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level are more likely to develop tumor lysis syndrome. 

Management: Aggressive hydration and administration of allopurinol at the same time as fludarabine are used to reduce the incidence of tumor lysis syndrome. Febuxostat, a non-selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used to treat hyperuricemia. It does not require dose calculations and can be used in patients with mildly decreased renal function. 

Rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase, may also be used in patients with renal failure. Hemodialysis can be done in severe cases not responding to treatment. 

Other options:

Option B - Chronic kidney disease would have a long-term history of impaired kidney function. This patient’s kidney dysfunction is of recent onset. In addition, his laboratory values are more suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome. 

Option C - Urate arthropathy (gouty arthritis) is not likely in this patient as he has no joint involvement. 

Option D - Nephrotoxic nephropathy is unlikely in this patient. Fludarabine is a purine nucleotide analog that causes myelosuppression, immunosuppression, fever, myalgia, and arthralgias.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common clinical feature seen in multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
The most common clinical feature that will be seen in multiple myeloma is bone pain. Bone pain occurs in more than 70% of patients with multiple myeloma and may be the presenting symptom. 

Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia in which there is unregulated proliferation of plasma cells. The proliferating cells stimulate osteoclastic activity and suppress osteoblastic activity leading to the formation of multiple lytic bone lesions. These lesions can be seen on radiographs as ‘punched out’ lesions.  In some severe cases, patients may present with pathological fractures. 

Other features of multiple myeloma include:

  • Acute renal failure in a dehydrated state
  • Normocytic normochromic anemia 
  • Hyperviscosity syndromes cause headache, exacerbation, or precipitation of heart failure, visual disturbances, ataxia, and vertigo
  • Bony damage leading to cord compression
  • Carpal tunnel syndrome
  • Sensory more than motor neuropathy associated with IgM directed against myelin-associated globulin

The single most important predictor for survival is serum β2-microglobulin. Serum β2-microglobulin along with serum albumin forms the basis of the International Staging System for multiple myeloma that predicts survival.


Other options: 

Option A - Frequent infections are common in multiple myeloma due to immunosuppression. However, bone pain is more common and is usually the presenting symptom. Pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus, and Klebsiella pneumoniae is most commonly seen. Escherichia coli causing pyelonephritis is also frequently seen.

Option B - Renal failure occurs in 25% of patients with multiple myeloma with hypercalcemia as the most common etiology. Tubular damage associated with excess light chain excretion is almost always noted leading to adult Fanconi syndrome, a proximal type 2 renal tubular acidosis. 

Option D - Visual disturbances like blurred vision can occur in multiple myeloma as a result of the hyperviscous state. It is seen as bilateral central venous occlusion, reflected as tortous and distended retinal veins. Hemorrhages and exudates also contribute to visual problems, however it is not the most common symptom.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with painful genital lesions as shown. On examination, there are enlarged lymph nodes. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Painful multiple vesicular ulcers in clusters on the genitalia and inguinal lymphadenopathy suggestive of Herpes simplex virus-2.

Genital herpes is more often caused by HSV-2. Genital herpes is characterized by vesiculoulcerative lesions (grouped vesicles with clear fluid in them) of the penis of the male or of the cervix, vulva, vagina, and perineum of the female. Recurrences of genital herpetic infections are common and tend to be mild.

Option A: Chlamydia trachomatis serovar L1, L2 and L3 cause lymphogranuloma venereum. The primary lesion is a small, painless, papulovesicular lesion appearing on the external genitalia. Lymph nodes are painful, enlarged and suppurate associated with scarring and lymphatic blockage. This leads to elephentiasis of the vulva in women called esthetiomene.

Option C: Chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi may also present with soft wide indurated painful genital ulcers and painful genital lymphadenopathy.

Option D: Klebsiella granulomatis causes donovanosis. It presents with a painless papule or nodule that erodes into a beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges. There is no lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen.

questions.text: During the normal delivery of a primigravida with polyhydramnios, an intern prematurely attempts to remove the placenta, leading to profuse bleeding. Examination reveals that the placenta is still partly attached and that the uterus is partly outside the introitus. The patient is in hemorrhagic shock, so initial resuscitative measures are taken. What is the appropriate management in this situation among the following options?

choices.text: Manual repositioning of the uterus alone
Attempt repositioning and administer a trial of tocolytics

questions.solution:
The patient is diagnosed with uterine inversion with the placenta still attached and the appropriate management in this condition is to attempt repositioning of the uterus and administer a trial of tocolytics.

The given clinical scenario of hemorrhagic shock after attempts of forceful removal of the placenta is suggestive of uterine inversion. It is a hemorrhagic complication encountered in the puerperium. Polyhydramnios in this patient contribute to uterine atony.

Risk factors for uterine inversion include:

  • Fundal attachment of the placenta
  • Uterine atony
  • Attempts at cord traction before placental delivery
  • Adherent placenta

There are 3 degrees of uterine inversion:

  • First-degree - the fundus of the uterus inverts into the uterine cavity
  • Second-degree - the uterine fundus protrudes through the cervix and lies in the vagina
  • Third-degree -  the whole of the uterus is inverted and protrudes through the introitus

Since uterine inversion presents with profuse bleeding and a severe degree of shock, it requires prompt diagnosis and management. Management includes:

  • Call for help and arrange blood products.
  • Evaluate for general anaesthesia.
  • Administer rapid crystalloid infusion through a large-bore IV cannula.
  • If the placenta has separated and the uterus recently inverted - The uterus is replaced by manually pushing up on the fundus with the palm and fingers in the direction of the long axis of the vagina.
  • If the placenta is still attached-
    • Attempt repositioning and administering a trial of tocolytics (Option C). This trial of tocolytics helps in uterine relaxation and also repositioning of the uterus. Terbutaline, magnesium sulfate, or nitroglycerin may be used. Once the uterus is repositioned, the placenta is removed manually. 
    • In case the attempt to reposition fails, the placenta is peeled off and once again uterine repositioning is attempted. Once the anatomy is restored, tocolytics are withheld and ureterotonic agents are started. Manual pressure (Bimanual compression) is applied. (Option B)
  • A Bakri balloon is used to maintain the repositioned uterus. (Option D)
  • If repositioning fails, Surgical intervention(laparotomy) is indicated.

questions.text: A college-going student presents to you with the rapidly increasing power of glasses due to progressive myopia. You also noticed Vogt’s striae on slit-lamp examination, along with Fleischer's rings. These Fleischer's rings are seen due to ______.

choices.text: Copper deposition in corneal Descemet's membrane
Iron deposition in corneal Descemet's membrane

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient showing Vogt’s striae and Fleischer's rings on slit-lamp examination is suggestive of keratoconus.

Fleischer's rings occur due to the deposition of iron in the corneal epithelium. These are seen as brownish rings at the base of the cone of keratoconus, best seen under cobalt blue light.

Keratoconus is a progressive disorder in which central or paracentral corneal stromal thinning occurs, accompanied by apical protrusion and irregular astigmatism.

Other signs seen in keratoconus:

  • Direct ophthalmoscopy from a distance of half a meter shows a fairly well-delineated oil droplet reflex
  • Vogt’s striae: Vertical (rarely horizontal) fine, whitish lines in the deep/posterior stroma and Descemet's membrane
  • Munson’s sign: V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on downward gaze
  • Scissoring reflex in retinoscopy

The image below shows Fleischer's ring (indicated by the arrow) under cobalt blue light:

 

Note: Kayser-Fleischer rings are caused by copper deposition in Descemet's membrane of the cornea and are indicative of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented to the clinic with a history of progressive wrist pain. Examination revealed stiffness of the wrist joint. A radiograph of his wrist is shown below. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing an increased opacity of lunate due to interrupted blood supply is suggestive of Keinbock’s disease.

Keinbock's disease refers to the avascular necrosis of the lunate leading to progressive wrist pain. Patients present with tenderness over the lunate and stiffness of the wrist joint.

Option A: Sever disease or calcaneus apophysitis refers to the inflammation of the calcaneus growth plate in growing children. 

Option C: Kohler's disease refers to the avascular necrosis of the navicular bone. 

Option D: Osgood-Schlatter disease/ tibial tubercle apophysitis refers to the inflammation of the patellar ligament at the tibial tuberosity. It is characterized by a painful swelling just below the knee. It worsens with activity and is relieved by rest.

questions.text: A male baby weighing 1.6 kg, born at 34 weeks, has abdominal distension and hematochezia on the 16th day of life. He is apneic, bradycardic, and lethargic. He was fed only with artificial formula milk. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a portal vein gas shadow. What is the stage of disease according to modified Bell's staging criteria?
questions.solution:
Abdominal distension and hematochezia in a preterm baby exclusively fed on formula feed are suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The abdominal x-ray finding of portal vein gas shadow is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB, according to modified Bell's staging criteria.

  • Stage I - Suspected NEC

Necrotizing enterocolitis is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal x-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis- air in the bowel wall is diagnostic, and corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

The given x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows). It is seen as a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures, nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication of surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl presented with high-grade fever, and recurrent infections of her mouth and skin. Oral examination shows significant gingivitis and periodontitis. Postnatal history is significant for delayed umbilical cord separation. Identify the likely etiology of the patient's condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as leukocyte adhesion defect 1 (LAD-1) and the etiology is defective CD11/CD18 integrin.

The clinical scenario of high-grade fever and recurrent skin and upper respiratory tract infections with a history of delayed umbilical cord separation in a child is suggestive of leukocyte adhesion defects. Gingivitis and periodontitis are hallmarks of LAD-1. 

Leukocyte Adhesion Defects are autosomal recessive disorders of innate immunity characterized by recurrent infections in the presence of neutrophilic leukocytosis. LAD-1 is caused due to defective leukocyte adhesion because of mutations in the beta chain of CD11/CD18 integrins. As a result, neutrophils cannot adhere to intracellular adhesion molecules ICAM-1 and ICAM-2 expressed on endothelium and transmigrate through the vessel wall. The few neutrophils that do transmigrate fail to recognize microorganisms opsonized by complement iC3b. This results in defective phagocytosis and recurrent infections. 

Clinical features of LAD-1: 

  • Recurrent infections of the skin, upper respiratory tract, lower intestinal tract, and genital mucosa.
  • History of delayed umbilical cord separation.
  • Gingivitis and periodontitis are hallmarks of LAD-1. 
  • Classical signs of inflammation are absent.
  • Lab work shows significant neutrophilic leukocytosis >25000/mm3.

Allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is the treatment of choice in LAD-1.

Other options:

Option A - Defective LYST protein causes Chédiak-Higashi syndrome. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. It is characterized by progressive neutropenia, neutrophil granules, occult-cutaneous albinism, rotary nystagmus, recurrent infections, peripheral neuropathy with ataxia, and prolonged bleeding time. High-dose ascorbic acid can be given in a stable state and allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation is indicated in the accelerated phase.

Option B - Defective Sialyl-Lewis X receptor causes LAD-2. Neutrophils rolling and tethering are affected. Clinical features are similar to LAD-1 but neurological defects, craniofacial dysmorphism, and the Bombay blood group are unique to LAD-2. Patients with LAD-2 respond to fucose supplementation.

Option C - Defective Kindlin 3 causes LAD-3. Chemotaxis, adhesion, and superoxide formation are affected. It is characterized by Glanzmann thrombasthenia-like bleeding disorder with other clinical features similar to LAD-1. Management is similar to LAD-1.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient on long-term lithium treatment came to the emergency room with symptoms of acute gout. He was treated with indomethacin and colchicine. Later, he developed nausea, vomiting, ataxia, coarse tremors, seizures, and hyperreflexia. Identify the drug responsible for this and the mechanism of the interaction.

choices.text: Indomethacin decreases plasma protein binding of lithium
Colchicine decreases renal excretion of lithium
Indomethacin increases tubular reabsorption of lithium
Colchicine inhibits the metabolism of lithium

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute lithium toxicity. The drug responsible for this is indomethacin as it increases the proximal tubule reabsorption of lithium.

Increased reabsorption of lithium from the proximal tubules is also seen with other non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen, naproxen, and possibly aspirin.

The important symptoms of acute lithium toxicity are nausea, vomiting, ataxia, coarse tremors, dysarthria, seizure, and hyperreflexia. There is no specific antidote, and treatment is mainly supportive. In severe toxicity, dialysis is the most effective treatment.

Thiazide diuretics may also lead to lithium toxicity. Lithium competes with sodium for reabsorption. Diuresis leads to Na+ loss and compensatory Li+ reabsorption from the proximal tubule, leading to toxicity.

Important side effects of lithium are-

  • Fine tremors in therapeutic dose
  • Seizures
  • Significant weight gain
  • Nephrogenic diabetes inspidus
  • Hypothyroidism
  • T wave flattening
  • Worsening of psoriasis
  • Teratogenic effect causing Ebstein anomaly and floppy infant
  • Leukocytosis

Other options:

Colchicine is an antimitotic drug that is used in the treatment of acute gout. It acts by inhibiting microtubule and spindle formation and thus:

  • Arrests cell division in the G1 phase
  • Inhibits neutrophil-mediated phagocytosis 
  • Decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors IL-18 and IL-1β

Colchicine has many other effects that may cause depression of the respiratory center, an enhanced response to sympathomimetic agents, and induction of hypertension by central vasomotor stimulation. 

Important side effects of colchicine are:

  • Nausea and vomiting 
  • Diarrhea
  • Myelosuppression 
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Rhabdomyolysis

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text:
Identify the correct activity of the various relay points involved in the baroreceptor reflex when a patient suddenly stands up after lying down. ‘+’ Indicates activation and ‘-’ indicates inhibition

NTS- Nucleus tractus solitarius

CVLM- Caudal ventrolateral medulla

RVLM- Rostral ventrolateral medulla
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a sudden change in position of the patient from supine to standing causes peripheral pooling of blood and reduced blood pressure. Thus there is reduced firing of the baroreceptors which is characterized by  - Baroreceptor, -NTS, -CVLM, +RVLM.

Baroreceptors are stretch receptors in the walls of the hearts and blood vessels. They are stimulated by the stretching of the walls of the respective vessels when there is an increased volume or pressure in the vessel. They are important in the immediate management of blood pressure. The receptors of arterial circulation include:

  • Carotid sinus - present in the adventitia of the internal carotid artery just above the bifurcation of the common carotid. Afferent nerve innervation is by a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve called carotid sinus nerve.
  • Aortic arch - present in the adventitia of the walls of the arch of aorta. Afferent innervation is by the vagus nerve called aortic depressor nerve.

The receptors of low-pressure system/cardiopulmonary receptors are:

  • Atrial receptors -  present in the walls of the right and left atria near the opening of the superior and inferior vena cava and pulmonary veins.
  • Pulmonary circulation receptors.

The afferents from the baroreceptors activate NTS  by releasing glutamate. The NTS in turn activates CVLM by releasing glutamate. The CVLM on activation releases gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) which is inhibitory to the RVLM. The RVLM is the major excitatory source of the sympathetic nervous system. As it is inhibited, there is sympathetic inhibition thus reducing the blood pressure. The NTS also simultaneously activates the vagal motor neurons thus causing bradycardia. Thus,

  • Stimulation of baroreceptors is characterized by +Baroreceptor, +NTS, +CVLM, -RVLM.
  • Reduced firing of the baroreceptors is characterized by - Baroreceptor, -NTS, -CVLM, +RVLM.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was recently fired from work and he felt a strong urge to physically harm his boss. To try and control his urge he took up badminton to vent his anger. Identify the type of defense mechanism used by him.
questions.solution:
The defense mechanism used is sublimation.

Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism. It means to gratify an impulse by changing the end goal from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one. Sublimation of aggressive impulses generally takes place through games or sports. Sublimation allows instincts to be channeled and not dammed up or diverted. Hence, in sublimation, feelings are acknowledged, modified, and directed toward a socially valued/acceptable goal so that modest instinctual satisfaction is achieved. In the given scenario, the man sublimates his urge to physically harm his boss (socially objectionable) by taking up badminton (socially valued).

Other options:

Option B: Altruism is a mature defense mechanism. In altruistic defense, the person gratifies an impulse by providing service or help to others even though it can be detrimental to the person itself. Example: An alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center even though he may be poor.

Option C: Displacement is a neurotic defense mechanism. In displacement, the person carries out purposeful, unconscious shifting of impulses from one object or person to another. Although the object is changed, the instinctual nature of the impulse and its aim remain unchanged and this differentiates it from sublimation where the end goal is changed to a socially acceptable one. Example: A person may be angry towards their boss for reprimanding him and wants to abuse his boss by using foul language. Here, the person displaces his anger by being rude and using foul language to his parents at home. 

Option D: Projection is an immature defense mechanism. On a nonpsychotic level, projection involves attributing one's own unacknowledged feelings to others. At higher levels, it may include misinterpreting motives, attitudes, feelings, or intentions of others.
Example: A man wishes to cheat on his wife, instead he says that he is sure his wife is cheating on him. Here, he is projecting his own unacknowledged feelings on his wife. 

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum. His blood work showed raised LDH and AFP. Which of the following is the imaging modality of choice?

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase.

AFP - α-fetoprotein.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged man presenting with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum suggests the diagnosis of a testicular tumour. Blood work showed raised LDH and AFP, which are tumour markers for non-seminomatous germ cell tumours (NSGCTs). The imaging modality of choice is ultrasonography.

Testicular tumours are uncommon male malignancies. Seminomas generally occur in the 4th decade of life, while NSGCTs are common in the 3rd decade of life. Spermatocytic seminomas occur commonly in men older than 50 years.

Clinical features of testicular tumours are:

  • Occurrence in the specific age group.
  • Painless testicular mass is the usual symptom
  • Sense of scrotal heaviness
  • Abdominal or lumbar mass due to metastasis
  • Chest pain, dyspnea, and haemoptysis due to lung metastasis
  • Prepubertal interstitial cell tumours produce androgens, causing precocious puberty
  • Postpubertal interstitial cell tumours produce feminising hormones, leading to gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido and azoospermia.

The initial diagnostic investigation of choice is ultrasonography (USG). USG of the affected as well as the unaffected testis is done and is mandatory. Tumour markers aid in the diagnosis. Chest X-ray is done to detect 'cannonball' metastasis in the lungs.

Other options:

Option A - Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) is done to assess the thoracic, abdominal and pelvic areas for metastasis. Although it is essential in staging and monitoring response to therapy, it is not the imaging modality of choice.

Option C: Trans-scrotal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of testicular tumours.

Option D: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) may be used as an adjunct if ultrasound findings are equivocal or if the location of the mass is uncertain.

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.
